nodes.text: When a company founder decides to sell equity to outside investors for the first time, it is common practice for private companies to issue preferred stock rather than common stock to raise capital.

Preferred stock issued by mature companies such as banks usually has a preferential dividend and seniority in any liquidation and sometimes special voting rights. Preferred stock issued by young companies has seniority in any liquidation but typically does not pay cash dividends and contains a right to convert to common stock.

issued by mature companies such as banks usually has a preferential dividend and seniority in any liquidation, and sometimes special voting rights. Conversely, while retaining its seniority, the preferred stock issued by young companies typically does not pay regular cash dividends. However, this preferred stock usually gives the owner an option to convert it into common stock on some future date, so it is often called
A preferred stock that gives the owner an option to convert it into common stock on some future date.

. In short, it will have all of the future rights and benefits of common stock if things go well. On the other hand, if the company runs into financial difficulties, the preferred stockholders have a senior claim on the assets of the firm relative to any common stockholders (who are often the employees of the firm).

To illustrate, let’s consider Facebook, which was founded by Mark Zuckerberg, Dustin Moskovitz, Chris Hughes, and Eduardo Saverin from their dorm room in 2004. Facebook’s initial funding came from $15,000 (Saverin) and another $85,000 (Zuckerberg and his father). By July of 2004, Facebook had caught the attention of angel investors Peter Thiel (co-founder of Paypal), Mark Pincus (co-founder of Zynga) and Reid Hoffman (co-founder of LinkedIn). They invested about $500,000 of new capital into the young firm in return for 10% ownership.

As Facebook grew rapidly (reaching over 1 million users by the end of 2004), it needed more capital. Its first round of venture capital financing came in May 2005 with $12.7 million worth of Series A preferred stock sold to Accel Partners (Facebook’s angel investors also invested more capital at this point). A year later, in April 2006, Facebook closed its series B funding round with $27.5 million from a group of 5 venture capital firms.
The information given here for this and subsequent funding comes from the IPO prospectus (available on EDGAR at

It is important to understand that Facebook remained a private company after this transaction. Simply selling equity to outside investors does not cause a company to be public. Companies may remain private, meaning their shares are not listed on an exchange and they are not required to file their financial statements with the SEC, as long as the number of shareholders remains small. Later in this chapter we discuss the process of offering shares to the general public and thereby transitioning to public status. After this funding round the distribution of ownership was:

The Series B preferred shares were new shares of stock being sold by Facebook. At the price the new shares were sold for, Series A and the founders’ shares were now worth $397.65 million and represented 72.3% of the shares of the $550 million company. It is important to note that the increase in the value of Zuckerberg’s and the other founders’ shares was very uncertain when they founded the company. The value of the prior shares outstanding at the price in the funding round ($397.65 million in this example) is called the
The value of a firm’s prior shares outstanding at the price in the funding round.
. The value of the whole firm (old plus new shares) at the funding round price ($550 million) is known as the
The value of the whole firm (old plus new shares) at the price at which the new equity is sold.
. The difference between the pre- and post-money valuation is the amount invested. In other words,

data.alt: Post hyphen Money Valuation equals Pre hyphen Money Valuation plus Amount Invested

nodes.text: You founded your own firm two years ago. Initially you contributed $100,000 of your own money and, in return, received 1.5 million shares of stock. Since then, you have sold an additional 500,000 shares to angel investors. Now you are considering raising even more capital from a venture capitalist (VC). This VC would invest $6 million and would receive 3 million newly issued shares. What is the post-money valuation? Assuming that this is the VC’s first investment in your company, what percentage of the firm will she end up owning? What percentage will you own? What is the value of your shares?
After this funding round, there will be a total of 5 million shares outstanding:

nodes.text: . The post-money valuation will be the total number of shares multiplied by the price paid by the VC. The percentage of the firm owned by the VC is the number of her shares divided by the total number of shares. Your percentage will be the number of your shares divided by the total number of shares, and the value of your shares will be the number of shares you own multiplied by the price the VC paid.
There are 5 million shares and the VC paid $2 per share. Therefore, the post-money valuation would be

nodes.text: Funding your firm with new equity capital, whether it is from an angel or a venture capitalist, involves a tradeoff—you must give up part of the ownership of the firm in return for the money you need to grow. If you can negotiate a higher price per share, the percentage of your firm that you will have to give up for a specified amount of capital will be smaller.
Over the next few years, Facebook raised several more rounds of outside equity in addition to the Series B funding round:
Funding terms were private. Details are authors’ estimates based on media reporting.

In each case, investors bought preferred stock in the private company. These investors were very similar to the profile of typical investors in private firms that we described earlier. Angel investors invested early and some continued to invest in later rounds as well. The other investors were primarily venture capital funds and wealthy individuals, like Li Ka-shing and Bono. Microsoft purchased most of the Series C stock as a corporate investor.
